title: Each RMU has a primary and secondary power sources. The RMU …
caption_en: Each RMU has a primary and secondary power sources. The RMU 1 primary power source is the Left Essential bus and secondary power is Emergency Battery bus. The RMU 2 primary power source is Right Main Avionics bus; the secondary power is Right Essential bus.

title: If the primary power source is not available, the RMU will a…
caption_en: If the primary power source is not available, the RMU will automatically switch to the secondary power source.

title: The radio system has an extensive built-in-test. A test is i…
caption_en: The radio system has an extensive built-in-test. A test is initiated when power is turned on. This is known as power-on self-test, or POST, in short. If errors are detected during POST, results will be displayed on a Test Results window. The display will not proceed further unless the function key is pressed to continue.

title: If no errors are detected, the RMU will display the radio tu…
caption_en: If no errors are detected, the RMU will display the radio tuning page as shown.

title: If an error message is listed, the pilot should note the mod…
caption_en: If an error message is listed, the pilot should note the module associated with the error message and verify acceptable operation of that module by performing a pilot-activated self-test or PAST. In the picture above, a COM 1 RADIO" message is displayed on the System Test Results page. The crew may perform a PAST to confirm the serviceability of COM 1 radio.

title: To perform a PAST on COM 1: - Position the cursor in the COM…
caption_en: To perform a PAST on COM 1: - Position the cursor in the COM window. Verify that AUX ON is not annunciated on top. - Push and hold the button. The word TEST will appear in the COM window.

title: Continue holding the button. The words COM TEST will be disp…
caption_en: Continue holding the button. The words COM TEST will be displayed, indicating that the COM is performing a self-test.

title: Continue holding the button. Upon completion of the self-tes…
caption_en: Continue holding the button. Upon completion of the self-test, the words COM PASS in green will appear in the COM window if no error is detected.

title: If error is detected, then COM ERR in red will appear. The e…
caption_en: If error is detected, then COM ERR in red will appear. The errors identified by PAST indicate one or more internal parameters were found to be outside the test limits but may not necessarily indicate non-operation of the function. Pilot should verify operation of the function.

title: The Com frequency select is in the upper left corner of the …
caption_en: The Com frequency select is in the upper left corner of the radio tuning page. The COM window has two lines, displaying COM frequency. The top line is the active frequency, while the line below is the preset frequency.

title: Upon pressing the line select key adjacent to the preset fre…
caption_en: Upon pressing the line select key adjacent to the preset frequency, a yellow cursor will move to enclose that frequency. This step is not always necessary since the cursor is normally parked over the COM preset frequency.

title: When the cursor is overlaying the preset frequency, the freq…
caption_en: When the cursor is overlaying the preset frequency, the frequency can be changed by adjusting the tuning knobs. Touch the tuning knob to simulate changing

title: Pushing the transfer key flip flop the preset to active and …
caption_en: Pushing the transfer key flip flop the preset to active and the active frequency now occupies the preset frequency.

title: Below the preset frequency is the word TEMP in green followe…
caption_en: Below the preset frequency is the word TEMP in green followed by a number. In the above graphic, TEMP-3 is displayed in the COM window. If the store (STO) button is pushed, TEMP-3 will change to MEMORY-3 and the preset frequency will be stored in COM memory and in position number 3 of the 12 memories. Touch STO button to store

title: With the cursor still on the preset, pressing line select ke…
caption_en: With the cursor still on the preset, pressing line select key against the cursor changes TEMP to MEMORY and the cursor encloses the MEMORY nomenclature.

title: The MEMORY function is now electronically linked to the tuni…
caption_en: The MEMORY function is now electronically linked to the tuning knob. Turning the knob scrolls through all the 12 stored frequencies in the memory. For each appearance of the MEMORY and position number, the corresponding stored frequency is called up and displayed on the preset frequency line. Watch. Preset frequencies can also be viewed by selecting COM MEMORY on RMU PGE MENU. This was discussed earlier.

title: When the desired frequency is displayed, pressing the transf…
caption_en: When the desired frequency is displayed, pressing the transfer key will swap the active with preset frequency. When the swap has taken place, MEMORY changes back to TEMP again.

title: Another function available on the COM window is direct tunin…
caption_en: Another function available on the COM window is direct tuning. By pressing the line select key next to the preset frequency and holding it depressed for approximately two seconds, the preset frequency will disappear, and the yellow cursor box will now enclose the active frequency. With the cursor on the active frequency, it can be changed by the tuning knob.

title: Normal display is restored if line select key next to COM pr…
caption_en: Normal display is restored if line select key next to COM preset frequency is depressed for about 2 seconds.

title: An amber TX will appear at the top of the COM window when th…
caption_en: An amber TX will appear at the top of the COM window when the associated radio is transmitting. Its purpose is to indicate to the crew that the transmitter is on.

title: When the microphone is stuck for approximately 2 minutes, a …
caption_en: When the microphone is stuck for approximately 2 minutes, a beep will sound on the audio and a red MIC message will replace 10 seconds after that, the selected transmitter will automatically turn off, however, the receiving function of the COM is not affected.

title: If the microphone switch releases, the system resets and the…
caption_en: If the microphone switch releases, the system resets and the MIC annunciation disappears. By incorporating this microphone jammed feature in the system, it allows the affected frequency to be used by other aircraft to communicate with the controller.

title: Depressing the SQ (squelch) function key at the bottom of th…
caption_en: Depressing the SQ (squelch) function key at the bottom of the RMU causes the COM radio to open its squelch and allows any noise or signal present in the receiver to be heard. When selected, a SQ will appear at the top of the COM window. Pressing the button a second time closes the squelch and remove the annunciation.

title: A green narrow-band or wide-band annunciation will appear at…
caption_en: A green narrow-band or wide-band annunciation will appear at the top of the COM window to indicate narrow bandwidth or wide bandwidth is selected.

title: Pressing the top right transfer key on the COM memory page w…
caption_en: Pressing the top right transfer key on the COM memory page will toggle the receiver bandwidth from narrow to wide in the COM window and COM memory page. The power-up setting will be the same as what was selected at power-down.

title: The narrow bandwidth is normally selected to communicate wit…
caption_en: The narrow bandwidth is normally selected to communicate with current generation ground stations that have very tight frequency tolerance. In some areas of the world that utilize older ground equipment, wideband operation is required to properly receive ground transmission.

title: The NB or WB will be replaced with AUX ON when the (clearanc…
caption_en: The NB or WB will be replaced with AUX ON when the (clearance delivery head) is selected to the EMER mode. This was described in Clearance Delivery Head topic.

title: The organization of the NAV window which is at the top right…
caption_en: The organization of the NAV window which is at the top right corner of the RMU is identical to the COM window in that the top frequency is active and the bottom frequency is preset. The preset frequency will also have an annunciation indicating whether it is a MEMORY or a TEMPorary frequency.

title: Frequency selection, memory function and direct tuning opera…
caption_en: Frequency selection, memory function and direct tuning operate in the same manner as described under COM Operation.

title: The NAV window has an added function called DME split tuning…
caption_en: The NAV window has an added function called DME split tuning mode. Its operation is similar to the function called DME hold.

title: Normally, the DME frequency is automatically tuned along wit…
caption_en: Normally, the DME frequency is automatically tuned along with the NAV frequency it is associated with. However, depressing the DME function key at the bottom of the RMU allows the DME frequency to be tuned independently of the NAV frequency. In splitting the NAV and DME frequencies, it is not necessary to bring the cursor into the NAV window. Touch the DME button on the RMU.

title: Depressing the DME key the first time causes the NAV window …
caption_en: Depressing the DME key the first time causes the NAV window to split into two sections; the top section contains the active VORIILS and preset frequencies, and the lower section, now labeled DME, contains the DME active frequency in format.

title: In this condition, the DME may be tuned directly by simply p…
caption_en: In this condition, the DME may be tuned directly by simply pressing the line select key to place the cursor box around the DME frequency and re-tuning using the tuning knobs. This will change only the DME frequency. The frequency selected will tune only the DME module.

title: The VORJILS frequency may be selected separately by pressing…
caption_en: The VORJILS frequency may be selected separately by pressing the top right button to bring the cursor onto the preset frequency. Next, turning the tuning knob changes the preset frequency. Pushing the top right button again flip-flop the active and the preset frequencies. The frequency selected will separately tune the Nav Receiver.

title: During the time that the VOR and DME frequency are split, th…
caption_en: During the time that the VOR and DME frequency are split, the DME digital station identifier will appear following the DME nomenclature on the top edge of the DME frequency. Both the VORILS and DME audio ident can be received on the Audio Control Panel (ACP).

title: An amber H appears on the RMU to indicate that the distance …
caption_en: An amber H appears on the RMU to indicate that the distance display is not paired with the VORIILS navigation data. At the same time, on the display, amber H is seen after the DME distance.

title: Depressing the DME key a second time will cause the DME wind…
caption_en: Depressing the DME key a second time will cause the DME window to change from a frequency presentation to a TACAN channel presentation with W, X, Y and Z channelization nomenclature. This mode of operation allows access by the DME to all TACAN channel in all W, X, Y and Z operating modes.

title: Pressing the DME key a third time will cause the NAV window …
caption_en: Pressing the DME key a third time will cause the NAV window to resume its normal mode with active and preset frequencies displayed. It will also cause the DME to return to its previous condition of channeling with the selected NAV mode.

title: ADF operation is the same as COM and NAV tuning in that depr…
caption_en: ADF operation is the same as COM and NAV tuning in that depressing the line select select key beside the ADF frequency will place the cursor over the frequency to be changed.

title: Rotating the small tuning knob slowly will advance the frequ…
caption_en: Rotating the small tuning knob slowly will advance the frequency in kHz steps. This change will increase to 10 kHz steps when the large knob is used. The rate at which the frequency changes is dependent upon and proportional to the speed at which the knobs, small or large are rotated. Touch the tuning knob to change frequency

title: The RMU has the capacity to store one ADF frequency in the m…
caption_en: The RMU has the capacity to store one ADF frequency in the memory. This is accomplished by selecting the desired frequency, then depressing the STO function key at the bottom of RMU.

title: To retrieve this stored frequency from memory, the frequency…
caption_en: To retrieve this stored frequency from memory, the frequency line select key must be depressed for 2 to 3 seconds. Watch.

title: Repetitively depressing the line select key adjacent to the …
caption_en: Repetitively depressing the line select key adjacent to the ADF mode annunciation will step through the available ADF modes of operation.

title: Changing of ADF modes can also be accomplished by placing th…
caption_en: Changing of ADF modes can also be accomplished by placing the cursor over the mode annunciation, and using the tuning knobs to step up or down through the available modes.

title: Transponder operation is similar to COMNAV operation in that…
caption_en: Transponder operation is similar to COMNAV operation in that depressing a line select button beside the function desired will move the cursor to that location. Touch the highlighted line select key.

title: Either transponder 1 or 2 can be selected for used and contr…
caption_en: Either transponder 1 or 2 can be selected for used and controlled by either RMU. A number 1 or 2 will appear in front of the transponder mode in the ATC window on both RMUs indicating which transponder has been selected.

title: Because of the interlock feature which allows one transponde…
caption_en: Because of the interlock feature which allows one transponder to operate at a time, both RMUs will display the same information. Therefore, if a code or mode is changed on one RMU, the other RMU will track the change. To illustrate which RMU initiated the change, the mirrored change will be displayed in yellow. Watch changing of code on RMU 1.

title: Transponder 1 or 2 selection is by depressing the 12 button …
caption_en: Transponder 1 or 2 selection is by depressing the 12 button on either RMU with cursor anywhere within the ATC window, and the transponder is in an operating mode i.e. not in standby mode. Touch the 12 function key to change transponder to number 2 set.

title: The initial mode of the transponder is STANDBY. In the STAND…
caption_en: The initial mode of the transponder is STANDBY. In the STANDBY state, the transponder is not replying. The available modes are ATC ON and ATC ALT. 1 or 2 precedes the mode to indicate which transponder set is in use.

title: The transponder is switched from STANDBY to an operating mod…
caption_en: The transponder is switched from STANDBY to an operating mode by depressing the line select key adjacent to the mode line. Once the cursor has been selected, the mode line select key acts as a toggle to switch the transponder between the STANDBY mode and the active. The active mode and transponder set that appear depend on what were last used. Watch.

title: Once the transponder is switched from STANDBY to an active m…
caption_en: Once the transponder is switched from STANDBY to an active mode, which in this case is ALT ON mode, the mode is changed by using the tuning knobs with the cursor still on the operating mode field. Touch the tuning knobs to simulate changing of mode. The tuning knobs have no effect if the transponder is in STANDBY mode.

title: When the altitude reporting mode is selected, the altitude b…
caption_en: When the altitude reporting mode is selected, the altitude being reported to the interrogating radar station is displayed on the ATCITCAS page, which is accessed through the PAGE MENU. On the display shown (left picture), the second line from the bottom indicates transponder number 1 is active and is reporting an altitude of ft. from ADC 1 or 2.

title: To change the transponder code, first highlight the code wit…
caption_en: To change the transponder code, first highlight the code with the cursor. Then, using the large outer knob, adjust the left two digits; use the smaller inner knob to change the two right digit. Unlike the transponder mode which requires transponder to be on, the code can be changed at anytime.

title: The selected code may be stored into memory by depressing th…
caption_en: The selected code may be stored into memory by depressing the STO button while the cursor is on the transponder code.

title: To retrieve the code from memory, depress and hold the code …
caption_en: To retrieve the code from memory, depress and hold the code line select key for 2 to 3 seconds.

title: Depressing the ID button of the RMU (1 or 2) will initiate a…
caption_en: Depressing the ID button of the RMU (1 or 2) will initiate an approximate 18 second IDENT mode on the transponder. This action will also illuminate an ID annunciation along the top edge of the transponder window. IDENT can also be activated by depressing a button on the front of the inboard handle of either control yoke.

title: Normally, RMUs are used to tune their respective integrated …
caption_en: Normally, RMUs are used to tune their respective integrated navigation units INU and integrated communications units (ICU).

title: It can also be used to cross-tune the opposite Integrated Na…
caption_en: It can also be used to cross-tune the opposite Integrated Navigation Unit and Integrated Communications Unit if the opposite RMU is unserviceable. This is known as cross-side operation.

title: To perform cross-side operation, assuming RMU 1 is used to c…
caption_en: To perform cross-side operation, assuming RMU 1 is used to cross-tune Integrated Navigation Unit 2 and Integrated Communications Unit 2, first, ensure the cursor on RMU 1 is in any window except the ATC window. Second, push the 12 button.

title: When the 12 function key is depressed, RMU 1 will display th…
caption_en: When the 12 function key is depressed, RMU 1 will display the same information as RMU 2. However, the colour of the legends at the top of each window changes to magenta to make it more apparent to the operator that cross-side is selected. Changing any frequency on RMU 1 will affect the opposite radios.

title: The digit displaying frequency for COM, NAV, ADF and ATC cod…
caption_en: The digit displaying frequency for COM, NAV, ADF and ATC code are white when they been selected by the on-side RMU. The ATC mode is green when it is also changed by the same RMU.

title: They are yellow when they are remotely tuned by the 1) oppos…
caption_en: They are yellow when they are remotely tuned by the 1) opposite RMU

title: They are yellow when they are remotely tuned by the 1) oppos…
caption_en: They are yellow when they are remotely tuned by the 1) opposite RMU

title: They are yellow when they are remotely tuned by the 1) oppos…
caption_en: They are yellow when they are remotely tuned by the 1) opposite RMU 2) or 3) In this case, only communication and navigation frequencies are affected on RMU 1.

title: The ATC mode is green when the change is performed on that R…
caption_en: The ATC mode is green when the change is performed on that RMU. The opposite RMU tracking the change will display the mode in yellow. For example, if the transponder mode is changed to "1 ATC ALT" on RMU 1, the mode will be green on RMU 1, but yellow on RMU 2. Watch.
